review.title: Interacting Conceptual Spaces I : Grammatical Composition of Concepts
review.abstract: The categorical compositional approach to meaning has been successfully applied in natural language processing, outperforming other models in mainstream empirical language processing tasks. We show how this approach can be generalized to conceptual space models of cognition. In order to do this, first we introduce the category of convex relations as a new setting for categorical compositional semantics, emphasizing the convex structure important to conceptual space applications. We then show how to construct conceptual spaces for various types such as nouns, adjectives and verbs. Finally we show by means of examples how concepts can be systematically combined to establish the meanings of composite phrases from the meanings of their constituent parts. This provides the mathematical underpinnings of a new compositional approach to cognition.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In fact, most people who are able, able, able to determine for themselves what they want and what they want to do are able to determine for themselves.

sections.heading: 2 Categorical compositional meaning
sections.text: In this section we describe the details of the categorical compositional approach to meaning. We provide examples of semantic categories and grammar categories and show the general method by which the grammar category generates an idea of conceptual composition in the semantic category.

sections.heading: 2.1 Monoidal categories
sections.text: We begin with a brief review of some of the category theory underlying a categorical composition category. Definition 1. A monoidal category is a tuple (C,, I, α, ρ) in which • C is a category •, the tensor is a radio gate C · C in which we write A B for (A, B). • I, the unit, is an object of C The remaining data are natural isomorphisms, with components of type: • A, B, C: (A B), (B ', C).

sections.heading: 2.2 Compact closed categories
sections.text: A specific class of monoidal categories, the compact closed categories, will be of particular importance.Definition 2. A monoidal category (C,, I) is compactly closed when for each object A C objects Al, Ar C (the left and right duals of A) and MorphismsηlA: I A Al A A A A A A A A A A A A A A A A A A A A A A "A" A "A" A "A" A "A" A "A" A "A" A "A" A "A" A "A" A "A" A "A" A "A.

sections.heading: 2.3 Grammar categories
sections.text: Many algebraic gadgets exist to model grammar, as described in [6] for example. In this paper, we use Lambek's pregroup grammars because many grammars have a pregroup structure [28]. Moreover, pregroups can be considered compact closed categories. However, it should be stressed that our approach does not depend on pregroups and can be applied to other grammatical models. Definition 3. A pregroup is a tuple (A, · l, − r, ≤) where (A, · 1, ≤) is a partially ordered monoid and − r, − l are functions A → A that represent such a constitution group.

sections.heading: 2.4 Meaning categories
sections.text: Distribution models of meaning use vector spaces to represent the meaning of words. In this paper, we move away from this approach and instead opt for ConvexRel, the category of convex sets and convector relationships. Before describing this new setting, we first present the conventional vector-space approach as a demonstration of the categorical compositional method. This sets the stage for a detailed discussion of ConvexRel in later sections. One way to model meanings in a vector space is to use coexistence statistics [4]. The meaning of a word is identified by the frequency with which it appears in the vicinity of other words. First, select a collection of context words. These will be the base vectors. Then, analyze a large body of writing to determine how often words coexist with the context words. For example, suppose the word dog appears in the same context as cat, companion and vector.

sections.heading: 2.5 Putting it all together
sections.text: We now have all the necessary components: a grammar category and a meaning category. We used the examples of pregroup grammars and vector spaces, but we emphasize once again that the abstract method applies equally to two compact closed categories. Suppose we have a word sequence w1 · wn and a pregroup P. Let us further assume that wi Wi is the vector space associated with the linguistic type wi. The meaning of w1 · · · wn is calculated as follows: 1. Assign each word a pregroup element pi based on its linguistic font. Let us take the pregroup reduction rules (cups and caps) to the element p1p2 · · pn to obtain a simpler type x.

sections.heading: 2.6 Beyond standard categorial grammar
sections.text: A first rather trivial example of a functional word is "does," which can be explained by means of caps [11]: chickens cross streets. Things become more interesting if instead of just wires we introduce the idea of a multi-wire (also called spider [8]), which can have more than two ends, or less:. The way these wires behave is exactly like wires. The only thing that matters is: "either to be connected by a multi-wire or not." Consequently, several wires "fuse" with each other:................ These multi-wire sets can be defined in category theoretical terms for each symmetrical monoidal category, in which they are called commutative special daggers Frobenius structures. Example 7. Four-chain in the category Rel. One can define the relations X ×.

sections.heading: 3 Conceptual Spaces
sections.text: Ga � rdenfors juxtaposes his theory with both a symbolic approach to concepts and an associationist approach, in which concepts are presented as associations between different types of information elements. Concept spaces are structures based on quality dimensions such as weight, height, hue and brightness. Concept spaces are roughly interpreted as convex subsets of a concept space. Concept spaces have an internal structure based on how quality dimensions interact with each other. A pair (or set) of dimensions is called integral when assigning a value to one dimension requires assigning a value to another dimension. For example, the dimensions of color, saturation and value are integral in the HSV color space. Dimensions are called separable if values can be assigned to one dimension.

sections.heading: 4 The Category of Convex Relations
sections.text: In this paper, we look at a more general constellation that includes convex subranges of vector spaces, but also allows us to look at some other, more discrete, exemplary concepts. We begin with a series of conceptual combinations that we consider for a finite formal convex sum of elements of the X plane, in which the convex elements of the X plane include formal convex sum of elements of the X plane, in the pi plane, in the pi plane, the pi plane, the pi plane is 0 and pi plane. We write D (X) for the set of such sums. Here, we abuse physical notation to emphasize that our sums are formal, following a convention introduced in [16]. These sums can be thought of as probable distributions on the elements of the XA plane.

sections.heading: 5 Adjective and Verb Concepts
sections.text: In order to match the structure of the pregroup grammar, we need two different objects: a noun space N and a sentence space S. The noun space N is given by a CompositeNcolour Nkey, which describes different attributes such as colour and taste. A noun is then a convex subset of such space. In our examples, we take our sentence space as a convex algebra in which the individual points are events. Our general scheme can include other sentence space structures, such decisions are generally application-specific. A sentence is then a convex subset of S. We will now describe some examples of noun and sentence spaces, and then show how they can be combined to form spaces that describe adjectives and verbs. As soon as these types are available to us, we will show in Section 6 how concepts interact within sentences.

sections.heading: 5.1 Example: Food and Drink
sections.text: We consider a conceptual space for food and drink as our running example. Space N consists of the areas Ncolour, Nkey, Ntexture, so N = Ncolour Nkey NtextureThe domain Ncolour is the RGB colour domain, i.e. triple (R, G, B), 3 with R, G, B stands for intensity of red, green or blue light. Nkey is defined as the simplicity of combinations of four flavours: sweet, sour, bitter and salt. We therefore have Nkey = {~ t | ~ t = ∑ i wi ~ ti} (8), where I = {sweet, sour, bitter, salt}, ~ ti is the vector in a selected base of R4, whose elements are all zero, except the ith element, whose value is one, and ∑ i wi = 1. Ntexture is only the amount [0, 1] which ranges from fully liquid (0) to fully solid (1).

sections.heading: 5.1.1 Nouns
sections.text: Properties in the color domain are therefore specified with sets of linear inequalities, and colors in the taste domain are specified with the convex body of sets of points. We use Conv (A) to refer to the convex body of a set A.banana = {(R, G, B) | (0.9R ≤ 1.5R), (R ≥ 0.3), (B ≤ 0.1) · Conv ({tsweet, 0.25tsweet + 0.7tsweet}), whether it has been positively selected, 0.3tsweet}) or whether it is apple = (R, G, B) | R − 0.7 ≤ R + 0.7), (G ≤ 1 − R, 0.1), 0.7tsweet (B ≤ 0.7tsweet = 0.7tsweet = positive, 0.7tsweet = negative.

sections.heading: 5.1.3 Verbs
sections.text: To define the verb, we use abbreviations of terms, which can be easily calculated. For example, since green is an adjective, green banana is calculated by taking the intersection of green and banana, combining the inequalities by specifying the color property, which results in: green banana = {(R, G, B) | (R ≤ 1.5R), (G ≥ B), (0.3 ≤ R ≤ 0.7), (G ≤ 0.3), (B ≤ 0.1)} · Konv ({tsweet, 0.25tsweet + 0.75tsweet, 0.7tsweet + 0.3tsour}) × [0.2, 0.5] Although a complete specification of a verb in all nouns to which it might possibly apply, we limit our nouns to only bananas and beer, which are unable to overlap the sweet (1).

sections.heading: 5.2 Example: Robot Navigation
sections.text: We will now present another example that describes a simple formulation of robot navigation: We will describe our options between noun space N and sentence space S and show how nouns and verbs are formed.

sections.heading: 5.2.1 Nouns
sections.text: The types of nouns we want to describe are objects such as armchairs and balls, the Cathy and David robots, and places such as the kitchen and living room. In short, we refer to these nouns as a, b, c, d, k and l. These are given in the noun space N, which is itself composed of a number of domains: Nlocation Ndirection Nshape Nsize Ncolor... We first consider the kitchen and living room as defined by convex subsets of dots in the Nlocation domain, which define properties in the location domain as follows: pkitchen location = {(x1, x2) | x1 [0, 5], x2 pliving room location = {(x1, x2) | x1 ² pliving room location = [5, 10], x2 [0, 10]}, which can be represented as follows: Kitchen living room0 5 010x1x2Then the nouns kitchen and living room are given by these properties.

sections.heading: 5.2.2 Verbs
sections.text: In fact, it is as if it is. (...) It is a purely mental game in which it is a matter of leading people astray. (...) It is not as if people are being led astray. (...) It is not as if they are being led astray. (...) It is as if they are being led astray. (...) It is as if they are being led astray. (...) It is as if they are being led astray. (...) It is as if they are being led astray. (...) It is as if. (...) It is as if. (...) It is as if they are. (...) It is as if they are. (...) It is as if they are. (...) It is as if they are. (...) It is as if they are. (...) It is as if they are. (...) It is as if they are. (...) It is as if they are.

sections.heading: 6 Concepts in Interaction
sections.text: We have given descriptions of how the different types of words can be formed within our model of categorical conceptual spaces. In this section we show how the type reductions of pregroup grammar can be applied within the conceptual space of formalism.

sections.heading: 6.1 Sentences in the Food Space
sections.text: The application of Yellowadj to bananas works as follows: Yellow Banana = (1N · N) (Yellowadj · Banana) = (1N · N) ((− x, − x) | xcolour = yellow) · ((R, G, B) | (0,9R ≤ G ≤ 1,5R), (R, B), (B ≤ 0,1) · Conv (R, 0,25tsweet + 0,75tbitter, 0,7tsweet) · (0,2, 0,5]) = (R, G, B), (R ≤ 1,5R), (R, 0,25tsweet + 0,75tweet), (B ≤ 0,1), Frutsweet ({tsweet, 0,25tsweet), (tsweet), (tsweet), (tsweet), (tsweet), (tsweet), (tsweet), (tsweet), (tsweet).

sections.heading: 6.2 Sentences about Robot Movement
sections.text: In this section we describe how to calculate the meaning of sentences about robot movements. Our first example is the sentence "Cathy moves to the living room." To calculate the meaning of this sentence, we assume that Cathy has a position. Cathy moves to the living room = (N '1s N) (C'shifts to L) = (N '1s) (C '1s 2) (C '2s) (C '2s 2s) (C '2s 2s 2s) (C '2s 2s) | f '2s place, f '2s place, f (0). In line (11) further constraints apply to t and f' as described in Equation (10). This calculation gives us a series of continuous line segments that proceed from Cathy's position at the time t and end in the living room. We must now check whether this position is convex.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusion
sections.text: To do this, we have introduced a new model of categorical compositional semantics, the category ConvexRel of convex algebras and binary relationships that respect the convex structure. We consider this model as proof that we can describe convex structures within our framework. Conceptual spaces are often considered a broader mathematical structure, such as distance measurements and notions of convergence or fixed points. It is also possible to vary the concept of convexity, for example, by considering a binary relationship between convexity and convexity in a space as primitive and not as a blending operation. Finding a good environment for rich conceptual spatial models and integrating these structures into a compositional framework is one direction for further work.

sections.heading: Acknowledgements
sections.text: This work was partly funded by the AFSOR fellowship "Algorithmic and Logical Aspects in Composing Meaning," the FQXi fellowship "Categorical Compositional Physics" and EPSRC doctoral fellowships.

metadata.abstractText: The categorical compositional approach to meaning has been successfully applied in natural language processing, outperforming other models in mainstream empirical language processing tasks. We show how this approach can be generalized to conceptual space models of cognition. In order to do this, first we introduce the category of convex relations as a new setting for categorical compositional semantics, emphasizing the convex structure important to conceptual space applications. We then show how to construct conceptual spaces for various types such as nouns, adjectives and verbs. Finally we show by means of examples how concepts can be systematically combined to establish the meanings of composite phrases from the meanings of their constituent parts. This provides the mathematical underpinnings of a new compositional approach to cognition.
